introduction.p: You may have heard, The world is constantly changing. But the big question is How? Is there a pattern? In math, patterns have names.
Linear is the name of a pattern. A linear equationlinearequation may look like this y=mx+b and its graph is a straight line.
If you look at the data from a linear patternLinearpattern you will notice the data has a constant rate of change, in other words constant slope.

In this section we study a pattern in which something remains constant, but it's not the rate of change, it is the percent change. An exponential patternexponentialpattern has the characteristic of constant percent change.

subsection.title: Percent Change, Multiplication and the Growth Factor
subsection.p: I remember a committee meeting I attended a while back during which one member was reporting about college enrollment and how it was dereasing. He said, Enrollment has been down 20 \% each year, that's 60 \% down in the last three years. This individual was not in the math department.
While there may have been reason to for alarm, that point was lost on the fact that this individual did not understand percentages or how they worked.
Before we explore constant percent change, we should have a very good understanding of percent, what it means and how it is calculated.
Students may need a more in-depth review on the meanings of decimal equivalent and growth factor. Follow this link to an interactive review of that material: review
In short, to change a number by a percent, increase or decrease, we multiply.
For instance if we start with the number 8, then 8*1.25 means to increase the number 8 by one and a quarter of itself. You get all of the 8 and 25 \% more.
8*1.25 = 10 means that 10 is 25 \% greater than 8
On the other hand, if we again start with 8 then 8*0.75 is a fraction of 8. Not all of it, only a portion. In fact, it means 75 \% of 8.
Notice that keeping 75 \% of 8 automatically means a loss of 25 \%. The equation 8*0.75 = 6 says 6 is 75 \% of 8 which also means 6 is 25 \% less than 8.
The number we multiply by to get the percent change is called the growth factorgrowth factor even though it may actually result in a percent decrease.
Typically the growth factor is referred to by the variable b.
Given an initial value of 165, identify the growth factor b:

li.p: The expression 165(1.12) has a growth factor b = 1.12
The expression 165(0.081) has a growth factor b = 0.081
The expression 165(5.69) has a growth factor b = 5.69

introduction.p: Use the growth factor to determine the percent change on the given initial value. The growth factor is shown in parentheses.

li.p: Given 22(1.39) what is the percent change on the initial value of 22?
Given 7(2.41) what is the percent change on the initial value of 7?
Given 17(0.56) what is the percent change on the initial value of 17?

solution.p: The growth factor is actually composed of 1 \pm r where r is the decimal equivalent of the percent gain or loss.
A percent increase implies the growth factor b = 1 + r, (i.e. b \gt 1) while a percent decrease implies b=1-r, (i.e. b \lt 1).

li.p: Since the growth factor b = 1.39 is greater than 1 we have 1+r = 1.39. Solving for r we get r=1.39-1 = 0.39. This is the decimal equivalent of a 39 \%percent increase.
Since the growth factor b = 2.41 is greater than 1 we have 1+r = 2.41. Solving for r we get r=2.41-1 = 1.41. This is the decimal equivalent of a 141 \%percent increase.
Since the growth factor b = 0.56 is less than 1 we have 1-r = 0.56. Solving for r we get r=1-0.56=0.44. This is the decimal equivalent of a 44 \%percent decrease.

subsection.title: Linear vs. Exponential Patterns
subsection.p: Looking at data, numbers, is part of almost everyone's profession. We search for patterns in the data from past or current events to try to predict future events. We have questions, like

li.p: How long will a mechanical part last?
When can we administer the next dose of medication?
When will we get to our destination?

subsection.p: Two commonly used or found patterns are linear and exponential. The news is full of them.

em.q: The United States population grew by 0.7 percent in the last year, its smallest annual expansion in 80 years.

blockquote.p: Growth of U.S. Population Is at Slowest Pace Since 1937, Niraj Chokshi, New York Times December 22, 2016

example.p: Without saying it explicitly, this piece of information is describing a constant percent growth. This is an exponential model.

em.q: Even though the federal minimum wage has remained at $7.25 an hour since 2009, most Americans are now covered by higher minimums set by state and local laws – from Los Angeles to New York state to Washington, D.C. Organized labor and anti-poverty groups continue to push for $15 an hour as the new standard for all workers paid hourly, though given Republican control of Congress that prospect appears dim.

blockquote.p: 5 facts about the minimum wage, Drew Desilver, Pew Research Center, January 4, 2017

example.p: The pattern reported in this statement is describing constant rate (hourly rate of pay). This is a linear model.

subsection.p: Distiguishing between linear and exponential patterns is as easy as knowing the difference between addition and multipication. The patterns allow us to find formulas for linear or exponential situations.
A linear patternlinear patternconstant rate of change of constant rate of change is essentially repeated addition. A linear formula counts how many times you add the same number.
An exponential patternexponentialpattern of constant percent change is essesntially repeated multiplication. An exponential formula counts how many times you multiply by the same number.

subsection.title: A General Formula for Exponential Growth/Decay
subsection.p: Just like linear formulas have a their own particular characteristics or format, for instance y = mx + b, so do exponential formulas. In this part of the activity we use a table of values to find patterns that emerge from constant percent growth or decay to find a general form for exponential functions.

blockquote.p: FYI you will find the word compounded in the exercises that follow.

The process of repeatedly increasing or decreasing by a percent is called compoundingcompounding It refers to the fact that increasing or decreasing a number by a percent is really a change by a fraction that number. Therefore consecutive percent increase (or decrease) is always based on a fraction of a number that is already greater (or lesser) than the initial number. Compounding also tells us how often a percent change is calculated. Most often the term is used in finance, .
For instance, if the percent interest on a loan is compounded montly it means interest is calculated every month. Compounded annually means interest is calculated each year, etc.
In the expression 500*1.15*1.15*1.15 the value 500 has been increased by 15 \% compounded three times.

subsection.p: Now we have general formulas for both linear y=mx+b and exponential y=ab^{x} equations.

In the linear equation y=mx+b, b is called the initial value. On a graph it is the vertical intercept. The m represents the rate of change (slope). It tells us the rate of increase (or decrease) per unit input. The variable x counts how many times the rate of change is added to the initial value.

In the exponential equation y = ab^{x}, a is the initial value and b is growth factor. b tells us the percent increase (or decrease) per unit input. The variable x in this case counts how many times the growth factor is repeatedly multiplied.

Finding the growth factor per unit in an exponetial formula can be the tricky part. Many people get mixed up about percentages. We have been thinking in terms of constant rate of change (linear) for so long, we often think everything is linear.
We need a way to convert a statement like, 60 \% over 3 years into a statement about the percent growth per year.
Let's go back to the example I made earlier from the committee meeting I attended. Here's the quote again, Enrollment has been down 20 \% each year, that's 60 \% down in the last three years.
The person that made the statement was thinking linearly in a non-linear situation.
